labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: environment identification
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
As discussed in today's (13/12/2022) Veraison meeting, we need to include claims to identify the verifier's execution environment, for example:
* software release information (for Veraison it'd be core services and loaded plugins)
* TEE identification (e.g., evidence)

One question we need to answer is where does it belong?  To the core claims-set or into an extension claim?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Fixed in #12 with the introduction of the [verifier-id](https://thomas-fossati.github.io/draft-ear/draft-fv-rats-ear.html#section-3.1) claim.

issues.title: Simon's review comments
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
1. `ear.raw-evidence` - perhaps worth noting that this may be more relevant for auditors than for further processing
1. [Example in 3.3.1](https://thomas-fossati.github.io/draft-ear/draft-fv-rats-ear.html#section-3.3.1): could remove a few of the TV entries e.g/ Storage + Sourced data as another example of 'no claim made'
1. Veraison processed evidence: perhaps worth adding something about the 'verified' status of members here? (relates to the 'unprocessed evidence' conversations)

issues.title: add an optional nonce
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: To support cases where the request for evidence appraisal involves a challenge from the RP / Attester, we need to add an optional `eat_nonce` alongside the mandatory `iat`.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Fixed by #12

issues.title: support for composite attesters
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
In a [composite device](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-rats-architecture-22.html#name-composite-device) evidence is assembled from multiple independent sources.

An example is the [Arm CCA attestation token](https://developer.arm.com/documentation/den0137/latest), which consists of separate (and separately signed) pieces of evidence glued together in an [EAT collection](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-frost-rats-eat-collection/).

A use case that we want to support is that of a verifier which will not be able to single-handedly appraise the whole thing and will instead carry out a partial appraisal and pass what it's done to the relying party with a clear indication of what remains to be done.  This is not unusual in confidential computing scenarios where the platform verifier can be separate from the workload verifier and they need to be part of a coordinated verification process.

The current structure does not cope well with that situation
```
EAR = {
  ear.status => $ar4si.trust-tier
  eat_profile => "tag:github.com,2022:veraison/ear"
  ? ear.trustworthiness-vector => ar4si.trustworthiness-vector
  ? ear.raw-evidence => ear-bytes
  iat => int
  ? ear.appraisal-policy-id => text
  * $$ear-extension
}
```
because there's only one "global" trustworthiness vector.

One way to address the issue is to split the EAR into two: a "core" object harbouring the trustworthiness vector associated to a specific piece of evidence (alongside other contextual stuff that makes sense on a per-evidence basis), and an outer container that will group the information with "global" scope:
```
EAR-core = {
  ear.status => $ar4si.trust-tier
  ? ear.trustworthiness-vector => ar4si.trustworthiness-vector
  ? ear.appraisal-policy-id => text
  * $$ear-core-extension
}
```
and
```
EAR = {
  eat_profile => "tag:github.com,2022:veraison/ear"
  iat => int
  ? eat_nonce = nonce-type
  ear.verifier-id => ear-verifier-id
  ? ear.raw-evidence => ear-bytes
  submods-label => {
    + text => EAR-core ; the submod name is an identifier for the portion of appraised evidence
  }
  * $$ear-extension
}
```

--- 
* 01/12/2023 Edited as per https://github.com/thomas-fossati/draft-ear/issues/10#issuecomment-1380546331
---

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
This is very much inline with what we discussed today (12/01). One thing though, I think, it still has value, if the in the outer EAR Wrapper we relay the complete raw evidence as is, in line with the current design of relaying the raw evidence.

Please note it is quite different from inner raw-evidence which pertains to individual (core) sub-attester evidence.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> This is very much inline with what we discussed today (12/01). One thing though, I think, it still has value, if the in the outer EAR Wrapper we relay the complete raw evidence as is, in line with the current design of relaying the raw evidence.

Thanks for checking if my memory dump effectively matched the whiteboard :-)

You are right, raw-evidence pertains to the outer scope.  I'll update the data model sketch above.

comments.author: ericvoit
comments.body:
Adding text from email.   We should track what is below.

> we have a predefined/standardized system-wide tag so
> that a Relying Party doesn’t have to guess that the appraisal spans
> the whole system?

Sounds good to me.  Do you have a proposal?

> And if I read this right, we likely should be tracking an issue which
> talks about the relationship between the system-wide appraisals, and
> the appraisals for any actual subsystems.

issues.title: System-wide tag
issues.author: ericvoit
issues.body: We need a predefined/standardized system-wide tag so that a Relying Party know the appraisal spans the whole system.  When where there are submods, we need to talk about the relationship between the system-wide appraisals, and the appraisals for any actual subsystems.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
The "multiple submods" case materialises only when the appraisal is not complete.

An RP is not supposed to consume directly this kinds of EAR -- unless it's coupled with the Attester, which should be the exception in an AR4SI world.  In the "uncoupled" case, RP will need to forward this partial EAR to some other Verifier to complete the appraisal.

A complete appraisal will typically only have one submod, which has system-wide scope.

comments.author: ericvoit
comments.body:
I don't think it is decided that a complete appraisal will summarize all the elements of a system.  At least with routers, there are different levels of system distribution.  And you might have each line card requiring its own appraisal each has a TPM.  I can imagine there are server clusters which also will need to provide a distributed view.

We could update the intro to the EAR document to show that such aggregate attestations are out of scope.  And that would also be a way to close the issue.

issues.title: fix `base64-url-text` definition
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: As per https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/pull/364 this has been clarified to be "without padding".

issues.title: Policy and evaluated claims
issues.author: setrofim
issues.body:
A Relying Party (RP) may wish to know which evidence claims were used in arriving at the Attestation Result (AR), and, therefore, which were not. There is nothing in the AR that can be used to indicate that, and, arguably, there shoudn't be, as this pertains to the underlying attestation scheme (which the RP is assumed to be famailar with*), and the verifier deployment-specific policy evaluation. Both of these elements are encoded as part of the `ear.appraisal-policy-id` field.

Current description of `ear.appraisal-policy-id` is very brief, and gives no indication as to how it might be used. It may be worth expanding its description to call out that the field can be used by RP to identify whether the AR was generated in accodance with its understanding of the attestation scheme, or whether some third-party policy may have been applied.

(*The assumption is that if RP is participating in an attestation scheme, it would be aware of how that scheme functions, and therefore how evidence would have been used in arriving at the AR. If this assumption is unreasonable, a case can be made for providing a well-defined "scheme description", either as part of AR or, more likely, a separate channel that RP can process. However, tath woud be a bigger discussion that does not pertain to this Issue.)

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> The assumption is that if RP is participating in an attestation scheme

AR4SI allows, and promotes, full decoupling between Attesters and RPs, so this assumption should not hold in general.  (It could be for some deployments, though that should be the exception.)

> a case can be made for providing a well-defined "scheme description", either as part of AR or, more likely, a separate channel that RP can process. However, tath woud be a bigger discussion that does not pertain to this Issue.)

Providing an in-band, verifier-signed EAR signal that conveys this kind of information seems like a valuable addition in terms of improved transparency of the operations.

We should track this, as you suggest, in a separate issue.

comments.author: setrofim
comments.body:
> AR4SI allows, and promotes, full decoupling between Attesters and RPs, so this assumption should not hold in general. 

Note, all this is predicated on

> A Relying Party (RP) may wish to know which evidence claims were used in arriving at the Attestation Result (AR)

If  RP is only AR4SI-aware, and is agnositic of the underlying evidence (which is what, I assume, is meant by "decoupling" here?), then, presumably, RP would not care about how the evidence was used to arrive at the AR? So to be more explicit about what is being assumed here:

    "Given a Relying Party (RP) that wishes to know how evidence was used in costructing the AR, 
      the assumption is that the RP is then familiar with the attesation scheme".

I believe this should hold in the majority (all?) cases. Either the RP doesn't care about the evidience and only about the verifier's evaluation (AR4SI), or it has an understanding of the scheme.

What I'm suggesting in the footnote is that if this is not true, then there needs to be some sort of standardised "grammar" for describing the evidence in terms of it's use, that the RP can then interpret.

> Providing an in-band, verifier-signed EAR signal that conveys this kind of information seems like a valuable addition in terms of improved transparency of the operations.

Depends on what is meant by "signal" here.

If this is just taking about tagging/flagging evidence entries that were used by the verifier, then I don't see how that would add much itility?  If we're assuing that RP has no a-priory understanding of the evidence, telling it which part of that evidence were used in the evaluation doesn't really add any information.

On the other hand, a formalised, machine-readable eqivalent of the table here: https://github.com/thomas-fossati/draft-psa-token/issues/71, i.e. something that encodes the semantics of the evidence iterpretation, could potentially be useful.

issues.title: raw-evidence per submod?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: In a one-to-one conversation, @yogeshbdeshpande suggested that we add a "per-component raw-evidence" to each `EAR-appraisal` block.  Such _optional_ field would contain the raw evidence bytes that the specific submod is dealing with.  This allows a downstream Verifier to be agnostic of the top-level evidence format (i.e., `EAR.raw-evidence`) and only care about the Evidence of the sub-attester it has to process.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
Given the downstream RP is capable of consuming raw evidence as a form of Attestation Results, they may not require  an
  eat.submods statement. Hence, eat.submods should be optional and the combination of `( ? raw-evidence, ? submods)` should be non-empty. 
Note: a profile may qualify the raw-evidence to an expected value such as: `raw-evidence => bytes .cbor my-accepted-claims`

issues.title: `Via` info
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
In a face to face discussion the case was brought up about (optionally) recording information regarding each individual verifier in a chained appraisal.  

This can be useful in debugging pathologies.  (And also as a signal to detect - and break - loops in the processing chain.)

HTTP's `Via` field (https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#section-7.6.3) may be a good starting point.

issues.title: Veraison extension for key attestation
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: See https://github.com/CCC-Attestation/attested-tls-poc/issues/16

issues.title: use CMW for `raw-evidence`?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
[Ned's suggestion](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/B0UEwmLogoYZefkuV1CSX52Uu1c/):

_"Should `ear-bytes` be tagged in some way such as a `cmw` or CBOR tag that enables the downstream parser to determine which encoding schema to use to decode it?"_

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: IIUC, the gist of Ned’s suggestion is to reuse the cmw CDDL for `raw-evidence` rather than aliasing `ear-bytes` to cmw.

issues.title: add an attester-id claim into the top-level EAR
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Reporting a conversation with Ned from the CoRIM interim.

Add a claim that identifies the attester in the top level EAR structure.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: This is an identity claim that was used authenticate the Attester under which the Evidence is authenticated.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Which types would you expect for this claim?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> Which types would you expect for this claim?

`identity-triple-record` where the authenticated endpoint uses key identified by the triple and the accepted claims are inclusive of the `environment-map`. (Open: We may want to think about whether a `stateful-environment-record` might also make sense. Given the environment-map.instance-id is populated or in measurement-values-map where some form of instance measurement is populated.)

issues.title: "default" (error) submod
issues.author: setrofim
issues.body:
The spec mandates that an EAR contains at least one submod. Should we have guidance on what implementations should do when a sensible submod cannot be created (e.g. due to an error)?

Errors generated by a verifier can be broadly classified into two categories: those that caused by the input (the input is either erroneous or cannot be evaluated, e.g. due to the absence of necessary endorsements), and those that are agnostic of the input (OOM, communication failure, etc). The latter are typically communicated via a separate error state as part of the API (e.g. an error return code). The former should be communicated in the attestation result, as they pertain to the evidence submitted, and not a failure of the processing pipeline.

In the majority of cases, there is no problem in constructing a valid EAR to communicate the error condition -- if we know what the evidence is supposed to be, we know what the client is expecting the EAR to look like vis-à-vis the submods it contains. However, in situations where the nature of the evidence cannot be established, and cannot be inferred from context (the verifier can handle multiple different types of evidence), we do not know how to construct the EAR. An example of that is when Veraison cannot match the media type in the request to an appropriate evidence handler.

In such situations, the verifier needs to add a "fake" submod and populate the AR4SI to reflect the error condition. The question is what name should this submod be added under? This cannot be the submod name the client typically expects, as we do not know what that is. While this can be implementation specific, it maybe useful to reserve a particular name (e.g. "ERROR"), or at least have some non-normative guidance in the spec for this.

issues.title: ar4si suggests a different structure than current EAR
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
Reading the ar4si carefully, the structure of the EAR seems to break the intent of ar4si. I came up with the following CDDL.
```
;
; interpreted from reading ar4si 
;
ar-augmented-bundle = [ + $ar-augmented-type-choice ]
$ar-augmented-type-choice /= ar-augmented-map
ar-augmented-map = {
    &(signed-ar: 0) => signed-ar-map ; presumably ar-augmented-bundle is a COSE/JOSE/other payload?
    &(rp-pof: 1) => pof-type ; aka nonce
    &(v-pof: 2) => epoch-type ; time since appraisal
    * $$ar-augmented-map-extension
}

signed-ar-map = { ; note: this looks a lot like a comid triple
    &(identity-ev: 0) => $identity-claim-type-choice 
    ? &(trust-vector: 1) => [ + trustworthiness-claim-map ] ; results claims
    * $$signed-ar-map-extension
}
$identity-claim-type-choice /= stateful-environment-map ; contains identity triple

trustworthiness-claim-map = {
    &(tust-tier: 0) => trustworthiness-tier ; is associated with each trust claim
    &(trust-quanta: 1) => $trustworthiness-quanta-type-choice
    ? &(trust-policy: 2) => $policy-type-choice
    * $$trustworthiness-claim-map-extension ; note: RP may want to see the actual claims accepted by the Verifier and maybe provenance
}

trustworthiness-tier = &(none: 0, affirmed: 1, contraindicated: 2, warning: 3 )
$trustworthiness-quanta-type-choice /= bytes ; assigned by verifier based on appraisal policy
$policy-type-choice /= text ; could be a policy ID

$$trustworthiness-claim-map-extension //= (
    &(accepted-claims: -4711) => [ + conditional-reference-triple-record ]
    &(entailment: -4712) => $entailment-type-choice
)
$entailment-type-choice /= conceptual-messages ; e.g., CMW containing Verifier inputs
```

Specifically, ar4si expects the `trust-tier` is specific to each trust claim i.e., `trustworthiness-claim-map`. 
It also indicates each claim may be influenced by a policy hence a policy (or possibly a policy identifier in its place) is also associated with each trust claim.

ar4si describes the Attester identity as "Evidence" but really it is a verified identity claim. Given CoMID is used to define Identity claims, the comid.identity-triple-record is a reasonable structure that need not be redefined. 

ar4si doesn't try to limit the attestation results to what is defined in ar4si. For example, the Verifier has a set of claims it has determined are valid based on appraisal, aka `accepted-claims`, that simply can be copied into attestation results. This can be done by making `trustworthiness-claim-map` extensible and re-using existing mechanism for representing claims such as comid triples. This example happens to use `condition-endorsement-triple-record` but others could be meaningful. 

If for logging / audit purposes the Verifier inputs are desired, the conceptual messages used by the Verifier could be copied into AR as claims entailment. It might make sense to do this on a per claim basis. But if not, it might make sense to extend higher up, possibly at the `signed-ar-map`? 

Additionally, the `signed-ar-map` appears to have triples semantics in that it relates a triple subject, a stateful expression of the authenticated Attester, with a triple object, the set of asserted attestation results claims.  Possibly, it makes sense to model this as an attestation results triple? That would allow more fluid reuse of powerful expressions found in CoMID.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Hi Ned, thanks for the write up.

I am not sure I understand in which way EAR would break the AR4SI model.

Could you please point out exactly which design choices we made in EAR go counter the AR4SI philosophy?

Note that EAR doesn't aim to fully address the AR-augmented evidence topic.  Our goal is to provide a wrapper around a "trustworthiness-vector appraisal" with enough contextual metadata to be useful as a general purpose AR format.  The idea is that if one wants to build some sort of AR-augmented evidence, they can use EAR in conjunction with other Evidence - e.g., using an EAT collection with a well defined binder.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> Could you please point out exactly which design choices we made in EAR go counter the AR4SI philosophy?

The `trustworthiness vector` is zero or more `trustworthiness claims`. A `trustworhiness tier` is associated with "a specific Trusworthiness Claim".

This suggests the tier and claim are members of the same map.  The EAR places the `trust-tier` along side the `ar4si.trustworniness-vector`. Since the vector is a list of thing, there should be a trust-tier for each possible thing.

Ar4si describes `Trustworthiness Claim` as a quanta of: `instance-identity`, `configuration`, `executables` etc... OR any state the vendor requires implying it should be extensible. 
But EAR describes these as `ar4si.trustworthiness-vector` and models it as a map rather than a list/array and it is not extensible.

I'm not saying the ar4si description is necessarily the best solution only that the EAR assertions that it is using ar4si are not correct representations of ar4si based on my reading of the text. 
I also advocate the ar4si authors use CDDL to express concisely what it is they did intend.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> > Could you please point out exactly which design choices we made in EAR go counter the AR4SI philosophy?
> 
> The `trustworthiness vector` is zero or more `trustworthiness claims`. A `trustworhiness tier` is associated with "a specific Trusworthiness Claim".
> 
> This suggests the tier and claim are members of the same map. The EAR places the `trust-tier` along side the `ar4si.trustworniness-vector`. Since the vector is a list of thing, there should be a trust-tier for each possible thing.

I think there's a bit of misunderstanding here.

Trustworthiness (TW) claims are _"Specific aspects for which a Verifier will assert trustworthiness [...]"_

The specific TW claims are defined in [§2.3.4](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si-04.html#section-2.3.4), e.g., configuration, executables, etc.

These are the entries in the TW vector.  You can think of the TW vector as either a vector whose slot indexes have specific semantics (e.g., [0] is configuration, [1] is executables, etc.), like this:
```
TW-vector = [
  configuration: -128..127
  executables: -128..127
  ; ...
]
```
or an associative array (i.e., a map, like we do in [EAR](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-fv-rats-ear-00.html#section-3.2.1):
```
TW-vector = {
  &(configuration: 0) => -128..127
  &(executables: 1) => -128..127
  ; ...
}
```
But that's just an implementation detail.

Each TW claim is given a trust "quantum" in the -128..127 range with TW claim-specific semantics.  (Actually, some quanta 0, 1, and -1 have global semantics, but that's not important here.)

The -128..127 range is partitioned into 4 tiers - affirming, contraindicated, ... - and each tier is further subdivided into a standard and private space to allow deployment-specific extensions.  The tier partitioning is nice cos even if the RP doesn't know the exact semantics of a given value for a certain TW claim, it can always map it into one of the four broad categories and design the policy accordingly.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
`$ar4si.trustworthiness-claim` ought to be `$ar4si.trustworthiness-quantum`
The "claim" is the tuple consisting of the claim type, e.g., "configuration" code point and the quantum value. 


Given: "Trustworthiness Tier: a categorization of the levels of trustworthiness which may be assigned by a Verifier to **a specific** Trustworthiness Claim." 
It seems the tier should apply to each claim in the TW-vector map. Namely:
```
TW-vector = {
     ? &(instance-identity: 0) => [ quantum: -128..127, tier: $trusworthiness-tier ]
...
     * $$TW-vector-extension
}
```
The `TW-vector` above should be extensible IMO.

As an aside, I don't agree with quantum=1 since an Attester can assert Claims that don't have corresponding Reference Values. Appraisal doesn't fail.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> `$ar4si.trustworthiness-claim` ought to be `$ar4si.trustworthiness-quantum` The "claim" is the tuple consisting of the claim type, e.g., "configuration" code point and the quantum value.

Sure, we can adjust that.

> Given: "Trustworthiness Tier: a categorization of the levels of trustworthiness which may be assigned by a Verifier to **a specific** Trustworthiness Claim." It seems the tier should apply to each claim in the TW-vector map. Namely:
> 
> ```
> TW-vector = {
>      ? &(instance-identity: 0) => [ quantum: -128..127, tier: $trusworthiness-tier ]
> ...
>      * $$TW-vector-extension
> }
> ```

`tier` is implicit in the `quantum` value.

> The `TW-vector` above should be extensible IMO.
> 
> As an aside, I don't agree with quantum=1 since an Attester can assert Claims that don't have corresponding Reference Values. Appraisal doesn't fail.

Sure, our initial thinking was that a different profile would be minted for a different/extended configuration of claims.

comments.author: nedmsmith
thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> > tier is implicit in the quantum value.
> 
> I can see how some of the tier values can be implied given a quantum value, but not all of them.

Hmm, no, all of them fall into one and only tier - see [here](https://github.com/veraison/ear/blob/56656d34b587fa7dd1326309fd188e3b24e4910a/trustclaim.go#L459-L477) for the exact ranges.

> I'm also concerned about combinatorics. For example, what does a tier of `contraindicated` mean in conjunction with a quantum of -1? Does it mean appraisal actually didn't malfunction? I would be more comfortable if these were mutually exclusive.

I am not sure I follow, but if you are referring to `ear.status`, there's a rule to set it from the vector:

_"The value of this claim MUST be set to a tier of no higher trust than the tier corresponding to the worst trustworthiness claim across the entire trustworthiness vector."_

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: If the `configuration` claim is affirmed, say 2, and the `executables` claim is contraindicated, say -125. Then what is the status in terms of `ear.status`? Since `ear.status` is common for all TW-vector claims, and claims don't have to have the same quantum, `ear.status` seems to require a function that aggregates the various tiers.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Since `ear.status` is common for all TW-vector claims, and claims don't have to have the same quantum, `ear.status` seems to require a function that aggregates the various tiers.

exactly so, see [here](https://github.com/veraison/ear/blob/56656d34b587fa7dd1326309fd188e3b24e4910a/ear_appraisal.go#L28-L42)

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
The summary status is the least trusted tier of any tier? 
For example, if an environment is attested that doesn't process secrets and is rated at a tier of contraindicated, and another environment that does process secrets is rated at affirming, then the status will be contraindicated - even though secrets are protected?

comments.author: ericvoit
comments.body:
I had this discussion with Thomas last December.  While I am not actually a fan of the Summary status, it is directly calculable.  Which is good.

My worry is that it dis-advantages Verifiers which are more thorough than others.  At some point we will need to have the discussion on-list of the way the summary status might be used in the rules processing of a Relying Party.

Eric

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: Some of our thinking indicates that there will be a few values (claims) that are unchanged from reference / endorsement to RP. The RP will be aware of which components are expected to have those values. This may be in addition to summary or aggregate claims that may be originated by a Verifier.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Some of our thinking indicates that there will be a few values (claims) that are unchanged from reference / endorsement to RP. The RP will be aware of which components are expected to have those values. This may be in addition to summary or aggregate claims that may be originated by a Verifier.

we have seen something similar in "split verification" scenarios - in our case it's platform vs workload verification.  Veraison uses an [`annotated-evidence` extension](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-fv-rats-ear-00.html#section-4.5) for doing that kind of verifier-to-verifier communication.

issues.title: Using CoRIM as an EAR
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
CoRIM / CoMID triples are expressive structures that contain much of the verifier context already. Verifiers may generate partial attestation results corresponding to subcomponents in a device composition. CoMID triples such as `conditional-endorsed-triple-record` that has logic where given a set of accepted claims, a set of additional claims can be asserted. Attestation results fits this pattern where given a final set of accepted claims, the "attestation results" claims are asserted. 

The EAR structure expects to retain much or all of the verifier's appraisal context in addition to producing attestation results. The corim "accepted claims" concept seems to already contain this context. The EAR seems to focus on retaining evidence input to the verifier, but it is unclear if the reference and endorsement inputs are also retained? Given the output of the verifier is a description of the Attester's current or active state, the verifier's "accepted claims" set seems to be the most appropriate representation of the current state. It is unclear, outside of audit requirements, why the EAR needs to retain only evidence. It is also unclear, outside of audit requirements, why the original signers of evidence is retained. The EAR description combines the audit requirements with multi-stage verifier requirements and abstracts all the verifier inputs as 'bytes' or 'text' even though the actual inputs may already be available in RIM or tag formats. 

If CoRIM was used as the omnibus representation of verifier to verifier conceptual message, then little or no changes are needed to support it. The attestation results claims as defined by ar4si seem to be the outliers. However, using a triple similar to `conditional-endorsement-triple-record` the ar4si claims can be appended to a set of accepted claims. E.g.:
```
attestation-results-triple-record = [ 
  subj: accepted-claims
  obj: ar4si-claims
]
```
Ar4si-claims could be a structure that is based on comid `measurement-values-map` where extensions to this structure can define ar4si specific claims. E.g.,
```
$$measurement-values-map-extension //= (
  ? &(ar-status: -1) => $ar4si.trust-tier
  ? &(trust-vector: -2) => ar4si.trustworthiness-vector
  ? &(appr-policy-id: -3) => $policy-id-type-choice ; since RATS hasn't defined appraisal policies / out of scope
)
```
The current EAR is expected to be signed but doesn't define the signed container. If CoRIM  / COSE is used, the container signature block can be used to capture signer context such as the `iat` timestamp and `eat.nonce` nonces, or other context that is specific to the signing event. These can be added to the COSE `protected-header` field.

The CoRIM signer field could identify the verifier (as it already identifies the container's signer). 

The CoRIM also identifies the profile that was applied.

The CoRIM can identify other RIMs that are needed to construct the device composition and to discover all the needed verifier inputs. This context may be a reasonable structure for informing an auditor also.

In summary, CoRIM seems to already have mechanism to address most, if not all, the requirements of an EAR. 
Whether or not attestation results should be encumbered with audit seems like an important question for further discussion. It seems reasonable that there could be a system of multiple verifiers, and that the partial results of one verifier should be inputted to a downstream verifier. However, an auditing system might require a first verifier to log activity with a stand-alone audit system rather than rely on a downstream verifier. 

Downstream verifiers might expect upstream verifiers to have fully processed an attestation result for a subcomponent as the "partial attestation result". A device composition might be the basis for a layout of verifiers in a multi-verifier architecture. That implies each verifier acts relatively independently. The only consideration for interdependent attestation results is the EAR.status, a.k.a., $ar4si.trust-tier which the EAR draft interprets as being an amalgamation of all the components in a device composition. Certainly, an entity could walk a  device composition hierarchy where subcomponents each have an ar4si.trust-tier result and compute an aggregate trust-tier value based on an aggregation algorithm (e.g., compute the average). It might make sense to leave such algorithms to the Relying Party who is ostensibly already considering ways to manage overall security risk.

Nevertheless, even if the verifier mesh is expected to amalgamate trust "status", it would be easy to add another claim for that purpose by extending `measurement-values-map`.  E.g.,
```
$$measurement-values-map-extension //= (
  ? &(amalgamated-ar-status: -3) => [ amalgamation-algid, $ar4si.trust-tier ] 
)
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Hi Ned, thanks for this and apologies for the delay coming back to you.

I agree with you that CoRIM/CoMID provide an info model that is rich enough to model all that EAR already provides.  It's also got a few intriguing properties, especially in the intra-verifier use case where the chained verifiers are all CoRIM-based.

The thing is that EAR is (by declaration) an EAT-based serialisation, so I am not sure CoRIM is in scope here.  I.e., what you are describing above looks more like a CAR (CoRIM Attestation/AR4SI Results) than a EAR :-)

Re: modelling the "accepted claims" construct.  The approach we are experimenting with Veraison (which is captured in the `annotated-evidence` and `policy-claims` extensions) re-uses the EAT `Claims-Set`, which augments evidence claims with endorsed values.

issues.title: Add an example OPA policy
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: Add an example OPA policy that appraises a JWT EAR token.

issues.title: public keys as first class claims
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Especially when used as passport, a EAR may need to carry the public key of the attester as one of the claims.

We have experimented with this pattern in the [attested TLS PoC](https://github.com/CCC-Attestation/attested-tls-poc) where we minted the Veraison-specific `"ear.veraison.key-attestation"` extension (documented in -01).  However, this seems to be more generally applicable to any secure channel establishment (e.g., in confidential containers's [KBS](https://github.com/confidential-containers/kbs)).  It would therefore help promoting the claim to the `"ear."` namespace.

issues.title: Support for UCCS/UJCS?
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
Seems like you'd want UCCS or UJCS EARs -- lots of B2B over TLS for attestation results I'd expect.

As written, there's no option for this because CWT/JWT is a requirement.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
hi Laurence!

> As written, there's no option for this because CWT/JWT is a requirement.

Always signing the EAR was a conscious choice to link strongly an AR to the verifier that was responsible for the appraisal.  In cases where it is not necessary to carry the signature across (e.g., in multi-stage verification within the same trust boundary), it can be stripped away easily.

issues.title: baseline profile and derived profiles
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
We have observed a recurring pattern emerging in PSA, Arm CCA, and now EAR - see: https://github.com/veraison/rust-ear/pull/16, of using the EAT profile as a baseline and extending it.

The "extensibility" section should describe the mechanics in terms of deltas over the baseline profile, including suggesting a scheme for how to mint the corresponding new profile identifier in terms of the baseline.

E.g.: for a "CoCo 1.0.0" EAR, the associated EAT profile could be constructed using the fragment identifier as in `"tag:github.com,2023:veraison/ear#coco-1.0.0"`.

issues.title: Relax constraint that extensions must be maps
issues.author: setrofim
issues.body:
The spec currently mandates that `$$ear-extension` and `$$ear-appraisal-extension` are maps. The intent seems to be to encourage bunching of multiple claims under one top-level codepoint, to minimize registration namespace pollution.

However, the need to register claims already provides the pressure to do that, without needing to mandate it as a universal constraint. Additionally, this does not matter for private ranges. Finally, this is counter to how similar extension mechanisms work for CoRIM and PSA tokens (other EAT-based standards that allow extensions).

This constraint is unnecessary and should be removed. It should be replaced with a recommendation that for non-private claims, maps should be used to group multiple claims under a single top-level key (essentially, an application name space) to minimise the use of the public codepoint namespace.

issues.title: Support explicitly partial appraisals
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Looking only at the `ear.status` claim, there is no way to tell an RP (or a downstream verifier) that the appraisal conducted by the verifier is incomplete.  For example, if some relevant reference values have not been provisioned.

This is the case for CCA realms when no RIM/REMs/RPV reference values are provided, but the identity of the realm world can still be appraised by checking the RAK signature over the realm token and the RAK attestation made by the platform.  In such case, the realm-specific appraisal submod will be populated with _some_ but not all of the TV claims, and the `ear.status` computed accordingly, maybe with an "affirming" (but partial!) score, if the RAK checks out.

In that scenario, it'd be helpful to a relying party that does not inspect the TV to know that the appraisal is incomplete. The risk otherwise is it'd be tricked into thinking that everything is good when only _something_ is good.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
ear.status, which represent the overall status of Appraisal for an attester is intended to accomplish the same objective.

As per EAR specification Section 3.2.2 Trust Tiers:
`The trust tier type represents one of the equivalency classes in
   which the $ar4si-trustworthiness-claim space is partitioned.  See
   Section 2.3.2 of [I-D.ietf-rats-ar4si] for the details.`

Reading Section 2.3.2 Enumerated Encoding of [I-D.ietf-rats-ar4si]:

`Value 1: The Evidence received contains unknown elements which the Verifier is unable to evaluate.

An example might be that the wrong type of Evidence has been delivered. Another case is that of Evidence coming from a composite Attester:`

**`a Verifier may understand only part of it and leave as "unknown" the Trustworthiness claims related to features it can't appraise.`**

What we have not encoded and grasped fully is the semantics for Value 1: 

We should say, For SubMod: Realm Appraisal, we should state that PartAppraisal conducted, with each Vector Element 
been indicated accordingly..

Also one thing to note is that  $ar4si.trust-tier inside the EAR specification is capable of 
extensibility within its own right, so we should revisit the code space and recommend correctly, 
instead of polluting by inserting such indicators outside as suggested to avoid duplication and confusion!

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
I don't really get what you are proposing.  We probably need a chat.

Noting that we could just get rid of `ear.status` - which is a conceptually wrong object in AR4SI land - and be done with the problem described in this issue.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
I am ok, to get rid of tight coupling of status to [2.3.2. ](https://ietf-rats-wg.github.io/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si.html#section-2.3.2)[Enumeration Encoding](https://ietf-rats-wg.github.io/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si.html#name-enumeration-encoding) which is really for each trust vector like instance identity etc.

If we get rid of status all together, means RP needs to inspect each of the Trust Vectors and make its own judgement, without any overall feedback from the Verifier, which is painful!

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
`I don't really get what you are proposing. We probably need a chat.`

What I meant was : Have we explored:

Option a) Possibly using status value : 1 to indicate the same ??

Option b) Affirming has range 2 to 31, could we say for this Attester, 30 ==> "Affirming with Partial Evaluation"

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> I am ok, to get rid of tight coupling of status to [2.3.2. ](https://ietf-rats-wg.github.io/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si.html#section-2.3.2)[Enumeration Encoding](https://ietf-rats-wg.github.io/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si.html#name-enumeration-encoding) which is really for each trust vector like instance identity etc.

That's not what I was proposing.

> If we get rid of status all together, means RP needs to inspect each of the Trust Vectors and make its own judgement, without any overall feedback from the Verifier, which is painful!

That's AR4SI -  which hopefully is not particularly painful (otherwise there would be little sense to use it in the first place.)

The conceptual problem with `ear.status` is it flattens 8 dimensions into 1.
And in the process obviously lose vital information.
That's the main reason to avoid basing any decision on its value, and an excellent reason to get rid of it.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Option a) Possibly using status value : 1 to indicate the same ??

What "same"?
Where is value "1" taken from?

> Option b) Affirming has range 2 to 31, could we say for this Attester, 30 ==> "Affirming with Partial Evaluation"

affirming is a string:

```
ar4si.trust-tier-none = "none"
ar4si.trust-tier-affirming = "affirming"
ar4si.trust-tier-warning = "warning"
ar4si.trust-tier-contraindicated = "contraindicated"
```

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body: Value 1: is from https://ietf-rats-wg.github.io/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si.html#name-enumeration-encoding

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body: `Value 1: The Evidence received contains unknown elements which the Verifier is unable to evaluate. An example might be that the wrong type of Evidence has been delivered. Another case is that of Evidence coming from a composite Attester: a Verifier may understand only part of it and leave as "unknown" the Trustworthiness claims related to features it can't appraise`

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Not sure what the proposal is. If you look at the outer context of that sentence you'll notice that 1 is part of the `None` bucket.  So it's currently mapped to `ar4si.trust-tier-none = "none"`.

issues.title: Add expiration to token
issues.author: fitzthum
issues.body:
The EAR has an `iat` field and can contain a nonce. This captures some sense of whether the token is new and an opinionated relying party could use this information to determine decide whether a token is fresh.

That said, there is no way for the verifier to report what the life of the token is (without using an extension). To me it seems like designating how long the results are valid should be a core functionality.

While some parts of the token might be derived from the hardware evidence, which may or may not have a concept of expiration, other parts of the token follow from the configuration/policy of the verifier. Adding an expiration to the token can help capture that these verifier configurations can change, or that the evidence itself has some bounds. Generally it just seems prudent to have the token expire.

pulls.title: Clarifying updates
pulls.author: setrofim
pulls.body:
- Specify that the ear.status tier must be no higher trust than what is
  implied by the trust vector, but could be lower. This allows for the
  possibility that the deployment-specific policy would evaluate the
  evidence to be less trustworthy than the sum of its parts, without
  necessarily overriding the trust level of any individual vector claim
  (e.g. via a blacklist of specific devices).
- Clarify that ear.raw-evidence should include the signature if present.
- expand the meaning of "iat" claim name, as it is not immediately
  obvious. It _is_ explained in the linked reference, but expanding it
  here save the reader a click.
- Change "compute" to "evaluate" in the ear.appraisal-policy-id, as
  "compute" implies a higher level of rigidity than may be applied by
  relying (or some other third) party-provided policies.

comments.author: setrofim
comments.body:
## Policy ID calarification

Adding as a comment here, rather than in the commit message as not necessarily related to the EAR spec per se.

The way we currently use policy ID in Veraision is to identify additional evaluation policies. The definition for EAR implies that "policy ID" covers not only what we call a "policy"  in Veraison, but also the "scheme". Currently, if no additional policy is specified, and the evidence is evaluated only according to the identified scheme, we do not set the policy ID in the result. Should be setting it to a scheme-defined value instead?

pulls.title: extensibility considerations + barebones veraison
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body:
Add §4 about criteria for both application- and deployment-specific extensions
Add §4.1 to document Veraison (deployment) extensions

Also reflow text to fit 79 columns.

Preview at https://thomas-fossati.github.io/draft-ear/veraison/draft-fv-rats-ear.html

comments.author: setrofim
comments.body: The distinction between deployment-specific and application-specific extensions is unclear. I'm guessing that the former is specific to a particular instance (deployment) of  a service, and the latter is specific to a service, but common across all deployments of that service? If that is the case, then shouldn't the Veraison extensions be application rather than deployment?

comments.body:

We could probably use a mild encouragement: _"[...] its claims MAY be registered"_

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: cc @paulhowardarm
Should be `TPM_PARSEC` -- to be consistent with `TPM_ENACTTRUST`?

good question :-)

I "think" in this case it should be `PARSEC_TPM`, because Parsec acts as the RoT abstraction and could (in the future) drive a PSA backend too, and others as well.

So `PARSEC_PSA`, `PARSEC_DICE`, etc.
Hm, in that case, shouildn't it just be `PARSEC`? How is the backend relevant here?

The underlying evidence formats are different: what Parsec does is it provides a single  API to request key (and platform) attestations, and uses a common encapsulation for the produced evidence.  But the encapsulated evidence is still in its native format, so different RoT backends will be associated to different Veraison schemes.

pulls.title: restrospectively add history log record for -01

pulls.title: nonce: align JWT and CWT representations
pulls.author: setrofim
pulls.body:
EAT had separate nonce definitions for JSON and CBOR, defining as a UTF-8 string for the former, and arbitrary bytes for the latter, resulting in incompatible representations.

For the EAR profile, to ensure compatibility between JWT and CWT, and allow maximum flexibility for the user, specify the nonce to be arbitrary bytes, base64-encoded when written as JSON/JWT.

See also the discussion here: https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/pull/421

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
In this patch we also need to align the CDDL, which at the moment has, for the JSON serialisation:

```
eat.nonce-type = text .size (10..74)
```

I wonder whether we should use `base64-url-text` like we do with all other "opaque bytes" types?

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
It seems like you have a choice to require the b64 encoding of the nonce either in EAR or in Veraison. EAR will have use beyond Veraison, right? I think, not all EAR use cases will require translatability between CBOR and JSON.

So, the nonce in EAR could be the same as the nonce in EAT (and OpenID) -- no requirement for b64. Then the restriction to b64'd nonces goes in Verasion. This gives more alignment with EAT.

You can specify the nonce in EAR is fully translatable between CBOR and JSON. That's kind of what this PR does. But it should probably go further to specify the EAR nonce the way EAT specifies byte strings like UEID making use of the the JC<> construct and such. Probably say that the comparison of the nonce in JSON is only after b64 encoding is removed.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> It seems like you have a choice to require the b64 encoding of the nonce either in EAR or in Veraison. EAR will have use beyond Veraison, right? I think, not all EAR use cases will require translatability between CBOR and JSON.
> 
> So, the nonce in EAR could be the same as the nonce in EAT (and OpenID) -- no requirement for b64. Then the restriction to b64'd nonces goes in Verasion. This gives more alignment with EAT.

We are already fully aligned with EAT, I think 😅 

EAR is an EAT profile that - among other things - constrains `eat_nonce`'s JSON type range.  And that's a proper profiling action, AFAICT.

> You can specify the nonce in EAR is fully translatable between CBOR and JSON. That's kind of what this PR does. But it should probably go further to specify the EAR nonce the way EAT specifies byte strings like UEID making use of the the JC<> construct and such.

We haven't used `JC<>` in EAR.

Instead we have abstract, "info-model" [labels](https://thomas-fossati.github.io/draft-ear/draft-fv-rats-ear.html#section-3-2) for keys and their types that get instantiated into the [JSON](https://thomas-fossati.github.io/draft-ear/draft-fv-rats-ear.html#section-3.3) and [CBOR](https://thomas-fossati.github.io/draft-ear/draft-fv-rats-ear.html#section-3.4) data-models.

> Probably say that the comparison of the nonce in JSON is only after b64 encoding is removed.

If the nonce has gone through a translation, yes.  That looks like a clarification we should add.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I see that you don't use JC<> and instead have separate CDDL for CBOR and JSON. You could probably use JC<> and get rid of most of the separate CDDL. EAT almost did.

EAT ran into trouble with nesting of CBOR in JSON and JSON in CBOR. The CDDL wasn't powerful enough.

It kind of looks like you require all submods to be the same encoding. You don't allow the sort of encoding that EAT does.

You are also defining your CDDL from the ground up, replicating CDDL lines, rather than referencing CDDL in EAT, UCCS, AR4SI and so on. I suppose that's OK as EAT does it, but that is sometimes considered bad practice.

EAT replicates out of necessity that came for a lot of IETF process and accidents. If UCCS/UJCS were defined first and fully as normative, then EAT could have just referenced it. Would have even been better if CDDL were invented before JWT and CWT.

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: LGTM, thanks!  One small correction inline: we need to use a normative (BCP14) "must" because the constraint we are establishing affects interop.

as JWT, the nonce MUST be base64 encoded, resulting in a string between 12 and
```

```

pulls.title: Import `ar4si`-specific types
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body:
Imports AR4SI-specific types from AR4SI.

See companion https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si/pull/29

comments.body: Should  `trustworthiness-claim` be here as well?
Should this `trustworthiness-tier` to align with the other types (or maybe change the other types to use `trust` rather than `trustworthiness`)?
Why use `eat.JC<>` here but `.feature "json"` and `.feature "cbor"` above?
yes.  However, this needs fixing in [upstream AR4SI](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si/blob/main/cddl/start.cddl) and then re-import.
makes sense, but again, it needs fixing in [upstream AR4SI](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si/blob/main/cddl/trust-tier.cddl) and then re-import.

The above is the result of `cddlc` automatically expanding the JC macro.
We could tell upstream not to expand.
see https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-ar4si/pull/32
ditto (link to the relevant AR4SI PR)
Ah ok, makes sense.
The `ar4si-autogen.cddl` in the `small-edits` branch on AR4SI does not expand anymore.
Addressed in [c454333](https://github.com/thomas-fossati/draft-ear/pull/44/commits/c454333b27d927cb81b7f6868f97cb30cd01e991)
Addressed in [c454333](https://github.com/thomas-fossati/draft-ear/pull/44/commits/c454333b27d927cb81b7f6868f97cb30cd01e991)
Addressed in [c454333](https://github.com/thomas-fossati/draft-ear/pull/44/commits/c454333b27d927cb81b7f6868f97cb30cd01e991)
